newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Yugoslavia needs aid to reach pre-war GDP-official.
newsitem.headline: Yugoslavia needs aid to reach pre-war GDP-official.

text.p: Yugoslavia warned on Wednesday it was unlikely to reach its pre-civil war GDP level by the year 2005 without financial help from abroad.
"Yugoslavia's goal is to reach the pre-war level by the year 2005 with an average annual growth of seven percent," an official from the government's centre for development and economics said.

"The projected growth, mostly based on a rise in imports, will be very difficult to reach without financial help from the International Monetary Fund and other financial organisations," said the official who declined to be named.
"Without fresh funds either domestically or from abroad, the country will not be able to develop or to service its debt," he said.
The violent disintegration of the former Yugoslav federation and international sanctions have been blamed for slashing Yugoslavia's GDP which fell to half its pre-war level in 1995.
In that year, GDP reached $15.9 billion, down by 44.7 percent against pre-war 1990. Income per capita last year stood at $1,500.

The official said existing differences between Yugoslavia, now comprising Serbia and Montenegro, and medium developed countries would widen further if the country could not reach its targeted GDP growth.
"The development gap will increase drastically," the official said. "And at that stage, no one will be interested in Yugoslavia as a country any more."

A Yugoslav delegation was due to begin talks with the IMF in Washington on Wednesday, hoping to bring down a so-called "outer wall" of economic sanctions which block the country's access to international money markets and finance. -- Gordana Kukic, Belgrade Newsroom 381 11 222 4254
